reviewText:
Absolute trash.

This isn't a game.  It isn't even a story.  It's a scam to get your $1.

This is how it plays out.  You press the right arrow key on your keyboard and you are shown a few 1-liner text boxes which have extremely poor grammar/spelling.  You get to the right side of the screen and cannot proceed further, so you turn around and above each text box appears another text box with another line of dialog and once you get back to the starting point it's over.  Press escape to quit the application.

You can't jump.  You can't press any other button in this game" except left
recommended: or escape to quit.\n\nThere is ZERO EFFORT HERE.  If free
hoursPlayed: I could barely see it having a place on Steam.  But for $1?  Why?  It's a waste of your 8 minutes.\n\nNot only that
voteText: but the developer has been removing all videos and censoring the discussions.  He deleted my threads and videos numerous times

giving me temp community bans[i.imgur.com] over it.  Why?  Why is my video of the game "against Steam terms and conditions" if it's just gameplay?  Developer is doing anything they can to prevent people from seeing what it is before they buy it.  There is no "terms or condition" for showing actual gameplay footage of a game.

reviewText:
Sharf isn‚Äôt a game for everyone, but it is very much a game for many. It‚Äôs a simple ‚Äúpixilated+‚Äù graphics game where a young woman walks through a dark and mysterious landscape filled with disturbing images. The only actions are walking and reading. It lasts no more than 10 minutes, but that is clearly stated on the Store Page, and Sharf costs less than $1US, and is now on sale for 10% less.

If you have lost someone to senseless violence, especially someone young and innocent, Sharf will be very worth your time, if only in the connection it will likely create between you, the DEV, and the community of like-minded gamers feeling this endless pain. There is minimal replay ability, but that‚Äôs hardly the point. The point is to remember, and to mourn, those we lost far too soon.

Sharf originally had some minor issues with imprecisely used English text, but they have been, or are, being addressed. Sharf has three guaranteed achievements, and if you‚Äôre a 100%er, this is an absolute gift for you.

I thank this DEV for creating Sharf, and reminding us that the pain is nothing more than a measurement of the love and trust people once shared. (I will never forget you, AP, who was violently killed at the same age.)

reviewText:
Sharf (scarf) is a simple, very short (10 minute) interactive memorial of sorts.

It may, or may not, depending on your sensibilities and life experience, create a connection between you, the dev, and others that have experienced pain and loss, especially from senseless violence.

For me, it worked"

reviewText:
Hmm, how to review... this?

Graphics:
It's black and grey, with two objects with colours. The animation is very basic.

Sound:
There's no music just some sound effects. They aren't bad, but they aren't great either.

Story:
There's no intro, only text bits that appear when you pass signs. I doesn't make much sense until you finish the 'game'.

Gameplay:
You press the right arrow key for about 4 minutes, then you press the left arrow key for the same amount of time.

Verdict:
I get what this is about after finishing the game, but it's nothing you should ask money for. It's not a game and adding trading cards to a 10 minute memorial is really pushing it. Yes, I do feel sad about the events that lead to making this... game, but asking for a dollar for it completely ruins the effect.

reviewText:
Okay, I wont pan this too hard because the game was made in dedication to a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and murder victim.

That said, I would have no idea that this was the premise of the game had I not read it on the final screen when you finish the game. Why? Mostly because it was fairly indistinct in this regard. Also, a lot of the text on your return bleeds over the initial set of text rendering it literally unreadable.

So, some positives: the music helped to set a somber mood. The imagery was interesting enough. It's nothing too extraordinary from a technical standpoint, but it does look cool. The melting crows/ravens, the nooses in moonlight, and so on do a lot to also help create a dark and somber mood. There is a cool death with sword image about halfway through. The ending also looked pretty neat.

The game itself is 2-D side scroller. You literally use the right arrow until you can go no further (at which point you will have unlocked two of the three achievements), then you head back the other way until the end, where you will unlock the final achievement.

Like I say though...at least for me, I had no idea what the game was really meant to convey until the ending script. Also, the game is 9 minutes long. I spent 89 cents of card farming cash on this game, and while I dont regret that choice, I think that maybe 89 cents is about 70 cents more than you should actually pay for this.

I'm going to offer it a 5.5 out of 10. I think for the dev this was a labor of love and probably a cathartic exercise as well. It was interesting for what it was.

reviewText:
This game cost me eleven cents per minute to play, and I got it on sale. While that is bad, it does say that it's short.

While it did cost me eleven cents per minute, I do still believe that it was a worthwhile purchase, and I think that I am in a better place because of it.

If you have lost a loved one and are still feeling the pain, as you likely will for a very long time, I recommend this game highly. You're not alone. I'm not alone. And it helps to know that. I'm grateful to the game's creator for this, and hope that they buy themselves an ice cold coke with the $0.89 I spent on this game. They deserve it.

Otherwise, give it a pass.
voteText: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
My full review can be found here.[www.the-backlog.net]

Sharf is an extremely short title following Christina in the woods. You'll spend ~10 minutes reading her thoughts until she finally finds a body.

This game is a dedication to a victim of a horrible act, and for that I commend it. While I do commend it, I also wonder why the money isn't going towards helping other victims of said horrible act. I detail this a bit more in my full review, but it would be nice to see if all proceeds went to help those victims. Aside from that, the game has a lot of ellipses, some odd grammar, missing words, and missing punctuation. While I get that these are supposed to be the internal thoughts of someone, the ellipses did make it a bit hard to read for me. Also, the game has no options, so no windowed mode or adjusting the sound.

Sharf gets a shaky recommendation from me. The grammar was rough in some parts, and the lack of options is never something I like.

*Note: The playtime is due to idling for cards and falling asleep while doing so.

reviewText:
You walk right.
You walk left.
It's over.
You're told it is in memory of a teenage girl who was ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and murdered.

Having a daughter myself, I can only imagine how horrible that is, but know that is every fathers worst nightmare.
I also know that if I were ever faced with such an experience, I would not confront it on Steam, with achievements and trading cards.  I find that to be disgusting.  Repugnant.

This is not a game.  It is an attempt to scrape some money off of a tragedy, and that truly is pathetic.
voteText: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is not really a game. It's a button pressing endurance contest. Train yourself to hold down the arrow keys for five mins before changing keys and holding that one for five mins instead.

I nodded off while playing struggling to hold down the button and get to the end.

I'm sure the message the developer gives at the end makes this a very personal project for them, but this doesn't really belong here as a game on Steam. Unless somehow the proceeds are going to the person's family mentioned at the end.

Really didn't like the art style of this... especially the legs of the main character. :/

Easily a skippable experience. I can't really recommend it though.
Overall 3/10.
Don't pay for this.

reviewText:
I made a childish and immature joke about this games title, and I promised I'd buy the game for real and check it out. I wound up deleting that joke thread when I found out what the subject matter is. At times like this, I wish I could a middle reaction.  Yes and no aren't really how I feel about this game. I'm going with yes because it's clicked by default.

I will not review this game. I'm not sure if it's worth a dollar but it is a dollar the dev will probably make better use of than I could. I think releasing it on Kongregate would have gotten more press honestly. I can't say I was overly emotional (there wasn't much external emotion at all, even in the ending), or that I liked the symbolism, but the game certainly affected me, even if it was just a feeling.

Think of it as a gamble. You can either potentially get some sort of an experience, or you waste 10 minutes of your time. It costs a dollar to play.

rip

reviewText: While this might not be a really long game, I believe that it should get more credit than it is. This game was not meant to be something that you play to have fun, it was meant to relay a message and a story to people. While there are some grammer issues, as well as text overlaying, the game was meant as a way for somebody to cope with the pain that they are facing. To me this game is meant more as a playable story and message, instead of your normal game. My condolences to the developer.

reviewText: I've seen worse 10-15 minute games being charged more than this game, so I don't understand why everyone is slamming it so hard when it's obvious someone worked on this and only charged $0.99 ($0.89 on sale) for people to experience it. Should it have been free? Yeah, I think so. Should people complain about losing a dollar for a game someone worked on for their amusement? No. I could buy a soda for a dollar and it would last half as long and I wouldn't complain. However, despite that, let me enlighten those who are checking this game out so that you can have an actual review of what the game is about.\n\nFirst of all, no, this game is not like Limbo, as I came in to expect it to be. It's more of what I can describe as an obscure pixelized narrative" of a game. You will not find much to do in this game

reviewText:
Imagine a poorly translated visual novel.  Now, instead of being able to skip through all of the rubbish dialogue, you have to crawl along through every piece of text s you walk from one end of the level to pick up a scarf.  But wait, there's more!  Once you have picked up the scarf, you get to repeat the journey all the way back to the beginning of the game where the game mercifully lets you finish.

I actually really dig the art style (apart from the weird leg animation), but there just isn't any substance at all.  When the main feature of your game is the story, having everything such a poor narrative is a cardinal sin.  I get that not everyone speaks English, and to appeal to the widest audience on Steam, games have to be in English, but when you're left scratching your head over certain sentences, it undermines the whole experience.  I might even be able to forgive some slip ups, but having text overflowing outside of speech bubbles is just plain lazy, especially on such a short game.

The only way I can recommend this, is if you're looking to pick up some easy achievements - you can complete the entire game with just three button presses - but for everyone else, it's just not worth your time.

reviewText: One of the easiest yet one of the saddest games I've played. I kept waiting for something to jump out at me reguardless of the creators assurance that there were no monsters. I loved the simplistic art style, it pulled me into the game and into the character.

reviewText:
While I'm sure this game has very personal meaning to its creator, and it's touching that they would create something in memory of a friend, it's unfortunately not a very enjoyable experience as a player.

The backdrop and background repeat as you walk to the right of the screen, reading signposts along the way that seem to express your character's inner thoughts. You find a red scarf at the end of the walk, only to walk to the left of the screen, reading the same signposts but with different text, until you find the ending.

As sad it is to hear about the creator's friend at the end of this, I really can't reccommed buying this game for any more than a few cents.

reviewText: I am all for indie developers and indie games and I give any game a chance but unfortunately I have to give this game a negative review simply for the fact that before the game even opened I encountered an out of memory exception. I am running this game on a decent gaming laptop and before writing the review I turned to the dicsussion board to see if there was a fix for the issue as I feel the game deserved a chance before recieving any negative review but the developer simply commented stange over a month ago and nothing more was ever said. Maybe its just me but as a developer myself I take pride in my work and sadly I feel that the developer doesnt care less about the game they have created. Maybe in the future after an update or two this review may change

reviewText: The entirety of this game is  holding down the right arrow to slowly walk accross a badly draw silhouette until you reach the end, then holding the left arrow to slowly walk back accross it again to get back to where you started. It took about 8 minutes for the round trip. A few ominous one liners appeared in text boxes along the way, but other than that there's no story. How did this even end up here on Steam?

reviewText:
If I wanted to get bored and pay 1‚Ç¨ for it, I'd go to the local strip club and ask Candy to read me one of her oh so dark poems she's so proud of - even the grammar would be similiar.

No, seriously... don't even bother buying it - if you want to play a game. The 10 minutes playtime in the discription are to be taken litteraly... you press 5 minutes on the right arrow, the next 5 minutes on the left arrow, and between that you read poorly translated English (I'm not perfect myself but c'mon... you're publishing a game here!). And even if you wanted to read the text (well... would be the only thing you can do), you won't even be able to because it does not fit in the bubble, gets cut off and thus unreadable.

In the end it says this game was made in honor of a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and murder victim, and thanks to that I don't feel my 1‚Ç¨ was totally wasted... I don't know who she was but my condolences to the dependents.

But in all honesty, there are only two reasons to buy this game (no matter how much it costs):
1) you want to pay respect to the dev and his/her cause
2) you want a quick perfect game
